ID.title: NeuroServer
ID.creator: NativeMinds
NativeMinds
info@NativeMinds.com
ID.description: NativeMinds is involved in the development of self-service interaction management software for the creation of automated online customer service and support agents called virtual representatives, or vReps. Created with NativeMinds' flagship product NeuroServer®, vReps are automated agents that answer customer questions via two-way, conversational dialog and rules-based display of relevant content from key corporate information sources, including Web site search, CRM knowledgebases, and customer-facing databases.
authoring tool for virtual representatives

ID.title: UMDHMM
ID.creator: Tapas Kanungo
University of Maryland, College Park
kanungo@cfar.umd.edu
ID.description: A simple implementation of HMM routines: Forward-Backward, Viterbi, and Baum-Welch. The notation used in the software parallels that of Rabiner and Juang.
an implementation of HMM routines: Forward-Backward, Viterbi, and Baum-Welch

ID.title: Conexor EngCG-2
ID.creator: Atro Voutilainen, Pasi Tapanainen and Juha Heikkilä
Conexor oy
info@conexor.fi
ID.description: EngCG-2 is a fast rule-based morphological tagger of English with a superior recall/precision tradeoff.
a fast and accurate rule-based morphological tagger of English

ID.title: EMERGE
ID.creator: O.Santana,J.Perez,F.Carreras,G.Rodriguez,Z.Hernández,J.Duque
Universidad de Las Palmas de Gran Canaria
osantana@dis.ulpgc.es
ID.description:
EMERGE (Flexionador y Lematizador de palabras del español) RECOGNIZES any Spanish word. It shows its canonical form, its grammatical category and the inflection or derivation it comes from. The same application generates the corresponding forms based on both a canonical form and an inflection or derivation. As regards VERBS, it deals with simple and compound conjugations, the appearance of enclitic pronouns, the inflection of the past participle as a verbal adjective (gender, number, superlative grade, and adverbialization) and the diminutive of the gerund. IN THE CASE OF NON VERBAL FORMS, it considers: gender and number of substantives, adjectives, pronouns, and articles; heteronimy caused by change of gender in substantives; superlative grade in adjectives and adverbs; adverbialization and adverbialization of the superlative in adjectives; appreciative derivation in substantives, adjectives and adverbs; multiple canonical forms in all the grammatical categories; invariant forms such as prepositions, conjunctions, exclamations, words in other languages and locutions or phrases. THE UNIVERSE of inflected and derivative 4.400.000 forms is composed of 123197 canonical words (without taking into account enclictic pronouns). The starting canonical forms cover all the entries of the Royal Academy Spanish Language Dictionary, the Vox Spanish Language General Dictionary, the Dictionary on Spanish Usage by María Moliner, the Great Planeta Larousse Spanish Language Dictionary, the Dictionary of voices of current use directed by Manuel, the Great Espasa Calpe Synonym and Antonym Dictionary and the Spanish Language Ideological Dictionary by Julio Casares.

Free internet use: http://protos.dis.ulpgc.es/morfolog/morfolog.htm
Online demo of morphological analysis of spanish texts

ID.title: EVALB
ID.creator: Satoshi Sekine and Mike Collins
New York University and University of Pennsylvania
sekine@cs.nyu.edu
ID.description: It evaluates bracketing accuracies. It reports precision and recall of bracketing and tagging accuracy.
Bracketing Accuracy Evaluation

ID.title: POSTAG
ID.creator: NLP lab (Geunbae Lee)
Postech
gblee@postech.ac.kr
ID.description: Korean morphological analysis plus part-of-speech tagging with morpheme dictionary.
korean morphological analysis plus part-of-speech tagging

ID.title: WinBrill
ID.creator: Gilles Souvay
INaLF
contact-winbrill@inalf.cnrs.fr
ID.description: WinBrill is the Windows95/98/NT adpatation of the Brill tagger trained for French (cf. J. Lecomte, INaLF). It includes a complete inflectional analysis system (cf. F. Namer, Université Nancy 2). WinBrill is also available for English tagging.
Adaptation of Brills tagger to Windows (for French and English)

ID.title: Babel
ID.creator: Stefan Müller
DFKI GmbH
Stefan.Mueller@dfki.de
ID.description: Babel is a Prolog System with Web-Interface in Perl and Java. Its main purpose is the test of an HPSG grammar for German.
large scale HPSG-grammar for German

ID.title: CLAWS
ID.creator: Roger Garside
UCREL, Lancaster University, UK
ucrel@lancaster.ac.uk
ID.description: A hybrid part-of-speech tagger for English, using HMM analysis and template techniques to achieve 96-97% accuracy. Recently used to POS tag circa 100 million words of the British National Corpus.
a hybrid part-of-speech tagger for English

ID.title: Conexor EngLite
ID.creator: Atro Voutilainen and Pasi Tapanainen
Conexor oy
info@conexor.fi
ID.description: EngLite is a fast and accurate parser of English capable of identifying low-level syntactic form categories from texts, e.g. basic nominal phrases, verb chains, certain kinds of postmofifiers. EngLite was primarily made for IT applications. Englite is a redevelopment of NPtool.
a fast and accurate light parser of English

ID.title: Conexor FDG
ID.creator: Pasi Tapanainen, Timo Järvinen, Atro Voutilainen
Conexor oy
info@conexor.fi
ID.description: FDG is a full-fledged dependency parser of English that assigns syntactic functions and dependency links to words (about 300 words per second). Sentence length does not considerably affect analysis speed. The dependency trees produced may be full or partial. Also non-projective constructions are handled by the new formalism.
fast and accurate functional dependency parser of English

ID.title: Link Grammar Parser
ID.creator: Daniel Sleator, Davy Temperley, John Laffferty
Carnegie Mellon University, Ohio State U.
sleator@cs.cmu.edu
ID.description:
The Link Grammar Parser is a syntactic parser of English, based on link grammar, an original theory of English syntax. Given a sentence, the system assigns to it a syntactic structure, which consists of a set of labeled links connecting pairs of words. As of July 2000, we are releasing version 4.0 of the parser. Among the new features of version 4.0 is a system which derives a "constituent" representation of a sentence (showing noun phrases, verb phrases, etc.).
We have made the entire system available for download on the web. The system is written in generic ANSI C, and runs on all platforms with a C compiler. There is an application program interface (API) to make it easy to incorporate the parser into other applications.
The parser has a dictionary of about 60000 word forms. It has coverage of a wide variety of syntactic constructions, including many rare and idiomatic ones. The parser is robust; it is able to skip over portions of the sentence that it cannot understand, and assign some structure to the rest of the sentence. It is able to handle unknown vocabulary, and make intelligent guesses from context and spelling about the syntactic categories of unknown words. It has knowledge of capitalization, numerical expressions, and a variety of punctuation symbols.
a syntactic parser of English, based on link grammar

ID.title: Pstone
ID.creator: Nigel Ward
University of Tokyo
nigel@sanpo.t.u-tokyo.ac.jp
ID.description: Pstone supports an assignment, typically taking 2 to 4 hours, which gives students: 1.respect for the complexity and idiosyncrasy of English syntax, 2.a sense of the trade-offs faced by grammar writers: low ambiguity, high coverage, simplicity, etc. 3.the desire to learn about alternative and complementary theories and methods. Pstone includes 1.a context-free parser 2.a corpus of 66 sentences annotated with parse trees 3.programs allowing evaluation of results, by visual comparison of trees produced by a student grammar with the "correct" parse trees 4.some supporting tools 5.documentation: an overview and the assignment.
CFG parsing package, for students to experience grammar writing (for English)

ID.title: TnT - Statistical Part-of-Speech Tagging
ID.creator: Thorsten Brants
Saarland University, Computational Linguistics
thorsten@coli.uni-sb.de
ID.description: TnT - Trigrams n Tags - is a very efficient statistical part-of-speech tagger that is trainable on different languages and virtually any tagset. The tagger comes with two pre-compiled language models, one for German using STTS, and two for English using the Penn Treebank tagset and the Susanne tagset. TnT can be adapted to any language model that delimit words with white space.
a statistical part-of-speech tagging for german, english and languages that delimit words with space

ID.title: CUF
ID.creator: Jochen Dörre, Michael Dorna
Institute for Natural Language Processing (IMS), University of Stuttgart
cuf-request@ims.uni-stuttgart.de
ID.description: Constrained-based language for specifying and processing linguistic descriptions (syntax, phonology, morphology and semantics). A typed, feature-based extension of Prolog.
constraint-based grammar formalism

ID.title: TG/2
ID.creator: Stephan Busemann
DFKI GmbH
busemann@dfki.de
ID.description:
Many intelligent applications that provide information or include a need to communicate are characterized by stereotypical formulations instantiating only a limited set of parameters. These applications allow for a complete a-priori structuring of the texts to be generated. This renders it possible to dispense with complex text planning and inference tasks that usually form a prerequisite for generating high-quality, readable text. It is perfectly adequate to address the problem with a more handsome approach.
It is for this kind of application that TG/2 offers a solution. TG/2 is organized as a classical production system, separating the generation grammar rules from their interpreter. Generation rules are defined as condition-action pairs. They can represent not only templates but also context-free grammar rules, using category symbols. Integrating these rule types into a single formalism allows for a shallow modelling of language where this proves sufficient, or for more fine-grained models whenever necessary. The interpreter consists of the standard three-step processing cycle: determine the set of applicable rules, select one from this set, and execute it.
Other features include personalized formulations through generic parameter settings and adjustable output formats (e.g. HTML, LaTeX).

An online demo for German, French, English and Portuguese is available at http://www.dfki.de/services/nlg-demo
a shallow generation system framework

ID.title: Alembic Workbench
ID.creator: D. Day, D. Zajic, J. Aberdeen, R. Kozierok, et. al.
The MITRE Corporation
day@mitre.org
ID.description:
Corpus annotation and development tool with graphical user interface. Annotations in SGML/XML are edited/viewed based on user preferences. Types of SGML annotation including simple "phrases" of contiguous text, "structured" tags that refer to other tags (via slot values), and a specialized interface that supports tagging co-reference relationships a la MUC. A template (event, relation) tagging interface is available that can be customized by users. Solaris and Linux versions can incorporate Alembic NLP system, including learning software to promote bootstrapping during corpus development ("mixed-initiative" corpus development). Supports UTF-8 (Unicode) and Latin-1 character encodings. Fonts for European and CJK languages included in distribution. Also included are KWIC tool, general scoring of SGML-encoded documents, among other utilities.

We are looking for partners to support Windows version.
a multi-lingual corpus annotation development tool

ID.title: Brainhat
ID.creator: Kevin Dowd
Atlantic Computing Technology Corp.
dowd@atlantic.com
ID.description: Brainhat is a program that can understand language, evaluate ideas, and ask and answer questions. This technology can form the basis for human interfaces to many kinds of applications. Because Brainhat is knowledge representation-based, brainhat can digress within a conversation, answer questions outside the script, and keep rich context. You can even answer a question with a question!
a knowledge representation-based natural language package (for English)

ID.title: INTEX
ID.creator: Max Silberztein
New York University
max.silberztein@univ-fcomte.fr <max.silberztein@un
ID.description: INTEX is a development environment that allows linguists to construct LARGE-COVERAGE descriptions of Natural Languages in the form of electronic dictionaries and finite state grammars, and to apply these descriptions to large texts (several million words in real time). Large coverage descriptions of French, English, Greek, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish are already available.
a development environment that allows linguists to construct large-coverage descriptions of Natural Languages

ID.title: Alembic
ID.creator: M. Vilain, J. Aberdeen, D. Day, J. Burger, et. al.
The MITRE Corporation
day@mitre.org
ID.description: Alembic is a multi-lingual text processing system. It incorporates a suite of low-level taggers, including part-of-speech tagging, sentence tagging, and word segmentation for a range of languages. Higher level processing includes "named entity" extraction, job-position /title tagging, noun-group/verb-group chunking, co-reference resolution, event extraction, tractable inference of interpreted facts, and more. Some of the languages for which systems have been built include: English, Spanish, Japanese, Chinese, French, Thai. Most of the system is trainable using error-reduction hill-climbing to produce transformational rule sequences. Currently developing dependency grammar parsing.
an end-to-end multi-lingual natural language processing system

ID.title: ALICE (Artificial Linguistic Computer Entity)
ID.creator: Rich Wallace
ALICE Artificial Intelligence
ID.description: ALICE is a natural language chat robot design to communicate with clients on the web, through a web-based chat interface. Like the deceptive machine hypothesized in Turing's Imitation Game, ALICE is a computer, pretending to be a man, pretending to be a woman, pretending to be a computer. ALICE won the Loebner Prize, an annual Turing Test, in 2000. A large number of applications use AIML (Artificial Intelligence Markup Language), the basis of ALICE intelligence.
ALICE and AIML (Artificical Intelligence Markup Language) for chatrobot development.

ID.title: LexGram
ID.creator: Esther König
Institute for Natural Language Processing (IMS), University of Stuttgart
cuf-request@ims.uni-stuttgart.de
ID.description: Grammar development tool and processing tool for unification-based lexicalist grammars(categorial grammar).
development and processing of categorial grammars

ID.title: Phrasys NLP Components
ID.creator: Oliver Mason
Phrasys
O.Mason@phrasys.com
ID.description: This is a set of re-usable components implemented as Java Beans. They cover tokenisation, sentence splitting, parts of speech tagging and phrase recognition. More components are under development.
A set of re-usable NLP components (for English) implemented in Java

ID.title: Sledopyt
ID.creator: MediaLingua
MediaLingua
webmaster@medialingua.ru
ID.description: Sledopyt search system gives you fast and effective document search means, based on document semantics. Search query is a natural language phrase, allowing interaction with Sledopyt as if it were a human. Sledopyt finds documents according to semantic likeness; words of query are scanned in all grammar forms; moreover, Sledopyt finds the necessary documents even if the meaning of query is presented in them in other words than there are in the query. Found documents are automatically sorted by degree of correspondence to query; all the words of the query are highlighted.
a search engine family for russian, german and english

ID.title: TiMBL - Tilburg Memory Based Learner
ID.creator: Walter Daelemans, Jakub Zavrel, Ko van der Sloot, Antal van den Bosch
ILK, Computational Linguitics, Tilburg University
Timbl@kub.nl
ID.description: TiMBL is a machine learning software package implementing a family of Memory-Based Learning techniques for discrete data. TiMBL stores a representation of the training set explicitly in memory (hence Memory Based), and classifies new cases by extrapolating from the most similar stored cases. The software is optimized for fast and accurate classification in discrete domains with large numbers of examples, as typically found in NLP datasets.
machine learning software package implementing a family of Memory-Based Learning techniques for discrete data

ID.title: Sunrise2001 CJK Pro Multimed
ID.creator: KEY CJK Word Processor
Asia Communciation Quebec Inc.
risingsun@msn.com
ID.description:
This software package also inlcudes the "KEY Pro" CJK Reading, Writing, Teaching & Learning software, which is a fully functional text processor with a natural language input system for CJK text on the computer. It has a Text to Speech component which reads any Chinese character text in natural (human voice based) Mandarin.
The customer can also download just parts of the system (i.e. the word processor).
a text processor with a NL input system for Chinese, Japanese and Korean, including a text to speech component for Chinese.

ID.title: ML Classification Server
ID.creator: MediaLingua
MediaLingua
webmaster@medialingua.ru
ID.description: ML Classification Server allows division of input stream of documents by predefined topics without using manual labour. ML Classification Server allows creation of hierarchy of topics for subsequent classification; it can also create a set of topics for division automatically, based on documents to be classified. Automatic classification algorithm is based on combined method of building a list of essential topics in documents with usage of statistical, morphological and syntactical data. By topic we mean word (noun), word combination (preposition-noun group in particular) or entire phrase. Weight (index of value) calculation is performed for each topic, allowing determination of topics of essence for a large number of documents. ML Classification Server is a server application for Windows NT platform. Speed of classification is about 1 Gb of text per hour.
Automatic classification for russian (english version soon available)

ID.title: Universal Translator Deluxe
ID.creator: LanguageForce
LanguageForce
sales@wforce.com
ID.description: Instantly translate web pages, email, documents and more in over 33 languages.
an omni-directional translation system

ID.title: WebBudget
ID.creator: J.M. Carreras and M.A. Currás
J.M. Carreras and M.A. Currás
info@webbudget.com
ID.description: WebBudget locates, classifies and counts all translatable text in an Internet file, including all ALT, BUTTON, META, JAVA, and MSGBOX labels. It also counts entire projects (folders + subfolders), from disk or online.
WebBudget is budgeting software for translators of internet documents

ID.title: LT TTT
ID.creator: Andrei Mikheev, Claire Grover, Colin Matheson
LTG, University of Edinburgh
grover@cogsci.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: The LT TTT system provides a flexible means of tokenising texts and adding markup at various levels. The main component of the LT TTT system is a program called fsgmatch. This is a general purpose cascaded transducer which processes an input stream deterministically and rewrites it according to a set of rules provided in a grammar file. Although it can be used to alter the input in a variety of ways, the grammars provided with the LT TTT system are all used simply to add mark-up information. We have provided grammars to segment texts into paragraphs, segment paragraphs into words, recognise numerical expressions, mark up money, date and time expressions in newspaper texts, and mark up bibliographic information in academic texts. The documentation provides a description of the rule formalism and the grammars so that users will be able to alter existing grammars to suit their own needs or develop new rule sets for particular purposes. While the bulk of tokenisation is performed using hand-crafted rules, the LT TTT system also contains components where the rules result from machine learning. The system has two components which were trained by the maximum entropy modelling method. The first is a part-of-speech tagger which assigns syntactic category labels to words, and the second is a sentence boundary disambiguator which determines whether a full stop is part of an abbreviation or a marker of a sentence boundary.
LT TTT is a text tokenization system and toolset which enables users to produce a swift and individually-tailored tokenisationof text.

ID.title: LT XML
ID.creator: Richard Tobin, Henry Thompson, David McKelvie, Chris Brew, Andrei Mikheev
LTG, University of Edinburgh
M.Moens@ed.ac.uk
ID.description: LT XML is an XML toolkit developed for processing large natural language corpora. It includes a set of tools sufficient for many applications and a C-based API to a validating XML parser and query language. The system includes full source code.
XML toolkit designed for processing large corpora

ID.title: xmlperl
ID.creator: David McKelvie
LTG, Edinburgh University
dmck@cogsci.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: Language to write XML transformations. Rule-based using LTXML(qv) query language. Rule bodies are written in Perl.
XML transformation

ID.title: LT POS
ID.creator: Andrei Mikheev
University of Edinburgh ; Infogistics
mikheev@cogsci.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: LT POS is a part-of-speech tagger which can handle plain ASCII text and SGML/XML marked-up text. LT POS incorporates a tokeniser which will determine sentence and word boundaries. The LT POS tagger uses a Hidden Markov Model disambiguation strategy. It achieves 95% to 97% accuracy.
a part-of-speech tagger handling plain ASCII and SGML/XML marked-up text

ID.title: LT CHUNK
ID.creator: Andrei Mikheev
University of Edinburgh; Infogistics Ltd.
mikheev@cogsci.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: LT CHUNK is a syntactic chunker or partial parser. It uses the part-of-speech information provided by a tagger and employs a mildly context-sensitive grammars to detect boundaries of syntactic groups. The chunker leaves all previously added information in the text and creates a structural element which includes the words of the chunk. Currently it is capable of recognizing boundaries of simple noun and verb groups.
a syntactic chunker or partial parser for English

ID.title: LT Thistle
ID.creator: Jo Calder
University of Edinburgh
J.Calder@ed.ac.uk
ID.description: LT Thistle is a parameterizable display engine and editor for diagrams, allowing the inclusion of interactive diagrams within Web pages. Originally designed for use with linguistic diagrams, it has widespread application within other areas involving the presentation and interpretation of highly structured information.
parameterizable display engine and editor for linguistic diagrams

ID.title: Annotate
ID.creator: Thorsten Brants, Oliver Plaehn
SaarlandUniversity, Computational Linguistics
plaehn@coli.uni-sb.de
ID.description: Annotate is an easy-to-use graphical tool for annotating sentences with syntactic structures that has been successfully used in creating the Negra corpus. Several commands are provided to build or modify an unordered tree based on the words of the current sentence and to change the labels associated with words (part-of-speech tag and morphological information), edges (grammatical function), and nonterminal nodes (syntactic category). In addition, so-called secondary links can be drawn between arbitrary nodes. These can be used for incorporating structure sharing information, e.g. to represent ellipses or to resolve anaphors. Other features of Annotate include a search function, basic tokenization commands (for splitting or merging words, moving sentence boundaries, etc.), postscript output, an undo function, and online help for the different label sets. Furthermore, an interface to an external parser/tagger has been implemented which suggests suitable part-of-speech tags, edge and node labels, and even entire phrases based on probabilistic methods. Suggestions judged unreliable by the parser have to be confirmed (or rejected) by the human annotator. This semi-automatical process has led to a great decrease in the amount of annotation time per sentence. Corpora are stored internally in an SQL database, together with the label sets employed in their annotation which are thus very easily changeable. Additionally, a line-oriented text format has been devised for import/export purposes and for use with standard Unix tools and in C programs. Tools have been implemented to automatically convert corpora between these two representations. Corpora stored in other formats (e.g. the Penn Treebank) can also be viewed or modified within Annotate after application of a straightforward transformation. To sum up, Annotate provides a comfortable and customizable graphical user interface that considerably eases the laborious task of syntactic annotation. For this reason it is already being used in a number of projects. Annotate is available for free for scientific purposes.
An easy-to-use, comfortable, customizable, and graphical tool for syntacticcorpus annotation. Annotate interacts with an external parser/tagger running inthe background.

ID.title: Entropizer 1.1
ID.creator: Aris Xanthos
UNIL/Linguistics dept
Aris.Xanthos@ling.unil.ch
ID.description: This freeware brings together a couple of tools for statistical analysis of textual data. Mainly, it computes and displays symbols and k-grams distributions and (conditional) entropies. Among other features, it is able to simulate text generation and to test for the order of the chain.
A toolbox for sequential analysis

ID.title: SEARCH
ID.creator: K. van de Veer, P. Wittenburg
MPI for Psycholinguistics
pewi@mpi.nl
ID.description: SEARCH is a tool written in PERL which allows the user to search in structured text files such as they are typically given in annotated corpora. It directly supports CHAT (Childes) and SHOEBOX format and it can easily be extended to other block-structured formats. The usere can specify patterns as regular expressions, associate them with tier (annotation layer) names, and combine them with help of a flexible logical language. If the corpus is block structured one can include block distances in the logical expression. If columns are supported as in SHOEBOX one can also include column distances. The user can link vector descriptions with the program which contain for example a definition of the set of vowels or fircatives etc. In the logical expression vector names can be used such that during pattern matching all options will be checked. The results are blocks which contain matched patterns. Currently, SEARCH is being extended by statistical functions.
SEARCH is a flexible search tool operating on annotated corpora

ID.title: Orthografix
ID.creator: Lingsoft, Inc.
Lingsoft, Inc.
orthografix@lingsoft.fi
ID.description: Orthografix 2 is a family of proofing tools for Microsoft Word and Adobe InDesign: spellers, hyphenators and inflecting thesauri for seven languages. Orthografix has the same user interface as the applications own tools, so you do not need to learn any new commands. All languages are sold separately. All versions are not available for all languages. More detailed information on Lingsoft's homepage.
proofing tools for Microsoft Word and Adobe InDesign (for German, Finnish, Danish, Norwegian, Swahil

ID.title: hdrug
ID.creator: Gertjan van Noord
University Groningen
vannoord@let.rug.nl
ID.description: Graphical Development Platform for Logic Grammars and Logic Grammar Interpreters
Graphical Development Platform for Logic Grammars and Logic Grammar Interpreter

ID.title: FSA Utilities
ID.creator: Gertjan van Noord
University of Groningen
vannoord@let.rug.nl
ID.description: Utilities for finite-automata
Utilities for finite-automata

ID.title: TextCat
ID.creator: Gertjan van Noord
University of Groningen
vannoord@let.rug.nl
ID.description: Language Guesser; knows about 70 different languages
Language Guesser; knows about 70 different languages

ID.title: LAIPTTS
ID.creator: Eric Keller & team
University of Lausanne
eric.keller@imm.unil.ch
ID.description: A complete French text-to-speech system. The system is based on extensive statistical and linguistic analyses of French grapheme-to-phoneme rules, phonological rules, prosodic scope rules, timing structure as well as melodic structure.
A complete French text-to-speech system

ID.title: Dan! 51 : CowBrain
ID.creator: Dan Sykes
None
dan@danyey.co.uk
ID.description: The beginnings of a system which will process much more than just language and the surrounding concepts, but thats its main function right now.
Simple language processor with a friendly cows face

ID.title: KPML
ID.creator: Bateman and many others
University of Bremen
bateman@uni-bremen.de
ID.description: Natural Language Generation Linguistic Resource Development and Maintenance workbench for large scale generation grammar development, teaching, and experimental generation. Based on systemic-functional linguistics. Descendent of the Penman NLG system.
Multilingual NLG

ID.title: DIMAP
ID.creator: Ken Litkowski
CL Research
info@clres.com
ID.description:
A suite of tools (version 4.0) primarily designed for creating and maintaining dictionaries for NLP, with easy upload of machine-readable dictionaries into DIMAP format and integrated WordNet. Includes tools for analyzing dictionary definitions, parsing them to identify semantic relations (such as hypernyms), mapping definitions across dictionaries, and identifying primitives using graph-theoretic techniques. Includes the functionality used in CL Research participation in Senseval and TREC-8 Question Answering, enabling research at the interface between the lexicon and text processing applications, using the integrated Proximity Parser (Proximity Technology, Inc. (c))
The DIMAP-4 beta version has just been announced (May 25, 2000). The source code for the Proximity Parser is available through CL Research (for academic and commercial use).
NLP Dictionary Maintenance

ID.title: The Quipu Maximum Entropy Package
ID.creator: Jason Baldridge, Tom Morton, and Gann Bierner
Universities of Edinburgh and Philadelphia
jmb@cogsci.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: The Quipu Maximum Entropy Package is a Java implementation of the maximum entropy framework. It allows you to train, evaluate, and use maxent models.
a Java maximum entropy implementation

ID.title: QuickTag
ID.creator: Michel Decary
Cogilex R&D inc.
Info@Cogilex.com
ID.description: Quicktag is a COM component for Win32 that can efficiently tag (identify the possible grammatical categories of words), lemmatize (identify the root form of words), disambiguate (indicate the actual grammatical category of words) and extract noun phrases from English text.
English tagger, disambiguator and noun phrase extractor

ID.title: The Quipu Grok Library
ID.creator: Gann Bierner and Jason Baldridge
University of Edinburgh
jmb@cogsci.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: Grok is a library of Java components for performing various natural language tasks. These include several preprocessing tasks (pos tagging, sentence detection, etc.), chart parsing, a large categorial grammar for English (induced from the Penn treebank), and some knowledge representation components (basic coreference, saliencetracking, etc.)
a library of Java components for performing many different NLP tasks

ID.title: The Quipu OpenNLP API
ID.creator: Jason Baldridge and Gann Bierner
University of Edinburgh
jmb@cogsci.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: The Quipu OpenNLP API is a preliminary collection of Java interfaces for standardizing how NLP components interact.
Java interfaces for NLP components

ID.title: Amalgam
ID.creator: Oliver Knorr
Abteilung Computerlinguistik der Uni. Erlangen
olk@gmx.de
ID.description: Amalgam is a Java applet that can be used to try out morphological and syntactical grammars for the Malaga NLP system (see the corresponding entry for the Malaga Tool in the NLSR) online from web pages. Several grammar examples are available for online testing.
a graphical WWW frontent in Java for testing Malaga grammars

ID.title: Festvox
ID.creator: Alan W Black , Kevin A. Lenzo
Carnegie Mellon University
awb@cs.cmu.edu
ID.description: Documentation, tools, scripts and example databases for building synthetic voices in new and supported languages. Includes complete walkthroughs for diphone, unit selection and limit domain synthesizers
Building Synthetic Voices

ID.title: FUF/SURGE
ID.creator: Michael Elhadad and Jacques Robin
Ben Gurion University of the Negev
elhadad@cs.bgu.ac.il
ID.description: FUF is an interpreter written in CommonLisp for a functional unification based language specifically designed to develop text generation applications. SURGE is a comprehensive generation grammar of English written in FUF.
FUG-based text generation for English

ID.title: Festival Speech Synthesis System
ID.creator: Alan W Black, Paul Taylor and Richard Caley
University of Edinburgh
festival-help@cstr.ed.ac.uk
ID.description: A general toolkit and full TTS engine for text to speech supporting a number of different APIs. Currently supports, English (US and UK) and Spanish, though other voices are being developed
text-to-speech synthesizer

ID.title: Light
ID.creator: Liviu Ciortuz
DFKI GmbH
ciortuz@dfki.de
ID.description: Light is a compiler for large HPSG grammars (notably the LinGO grammar for English). It is based on an abstract machine, and produces C code. Currently, the system is in an advanced development state.
Light - a compiler for large HPSG grammars

ID.title: TDL---Type Description Language
ID.creator: Hans-Ulrich Krieger, Ulrich Schäfer
German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
krieger@dfki.de
ID.description:
TDL is a typed feature-based language, which is specifically designed to support highly lexicalized grammar theories, such as HPSG,FUG, or CUG. TDL offers the possibility to define (possibly recursive) types, consisting of type and feature constraints over the Boolean connectives AND, OR, and NOT, where the types are arranged in a subsumption hierarchy. TDL distinguishes between avm types (open-world reasoning) and sort types (closed-world reasoning) and allows the declaration of partitions and incompatible types. Working with partially and fully expanded types as well as with undefined types is possible, both at definition and at run time. TDL is incremental in that it allows the redefinition of types. Efficient reasoning is accomplished through specialized modules.
Large grammars and lexicons for English, German, and Japanese are available.
System for linguistic analysis and test of linguistic theory (HPSG, FUG, PATR-II). Can be used as part of a deep NLP system or as part of a speech system (a special version is used in Verbmobil).

ID.title: PAGE: A Platfrom for Advanced Grammar Engineering.
ID.creator: Rolf Backofen, Bernd Kiefer, Walter Kasper, Hans-Ulrich Krieger, Günter Neumann, Stephan Oepen, Ulrich Schäfer
German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
kiefer@dfki.de
ID.description: The PAGE system developed and maintained in the Language Technology Lab of the German National Research Center on Artificial Intelligence DFKI GmbH is an advanced NLP core engine that especially facilitates the development of grammatical and lexical resources, building on typed feature logics (e.g., for HPSG-style frameworks). PAGE comprises a fair number of various (and often independent) modules and linguistic resources that allow for a flexible configuration according to different user requirements. PAGE has been successfully employed (inside and outside of DFKI) in both grammar development and application building; it has proven a sufficiently mature and robust platform for large-scale engineering (e.g., in the Verbmobil project or the ERGO consortium). Using PAGE, wide-coverage grammars have been written for German, English, and Japanese. The PAGE system is implemented in Common Lisp, ANSI C, and Tcl/Tk and builds on standardized graphical toolkits.
System for linguistic analysis and test of linguistic theory (HPSG, FUG, PATR-II). Can be used as part of a deep NLP system or as part of a speech system (a special version is used in Verbmobil).

ID.title: V-Stemma
ID.creator: Kimmo Kettunen
Regstrings
kettunen@kaapeli.fi
ID.description: Finnish verb stem generator, cf. Stemma, noun stem generator. Written in TAWK, compiled AWK.
Finnish verb stem generator

ID.title: Stemma
ID.creator: Kimmo Kettunen
Regstrings
kettunen@kaapeli.fi
ID.description: Noun stem generator of Finnish nouns. Works for most adjectives also. Written in Icon, older version of the program available from web, newer versions on request.
Noun stem generator of Finnish nouns

ID.title: POSPAR
ID.creator: NLP Lab (Geunbae Lee)
Postech
gblee@postech.ac.kr
ID.description: Syntactic Analyzer using Korean Combinatory Categorial Grammar formalism
Syntactic Analyzer for Korean

ID.title: POSNIR
ID.creator: NLP lab (Geunbae Lee)
Postech
gblee@postech.ac.kr
ID.description: Korean Natural Language Information Retrieval System (Search Engine, compound noun Indexer, NL query processing)
Korean Natural Language Information Retrieval System

ID.title: POSTTS
ID.creator: NLP lab (Geunbae Lee)
Postech
gblee@postech.ac.kr
ID.description: Korean text to speech system which converts general Korean text sentences into their corresponding phoneme sequences
Korean text to speech system

ID.title: DioMorfo
ID.creator: Delphes Technologies International
Delphes Technologies International
information@delphesintl.com
ID.description: A personal trilingual search engine for automatic searching, retrieving, acquiring and classifying of pertinent information in English, French and Spanish.
Information management tool in three languages supported by extensive thesaurus

ID.title: CSRE - Computerized Speech Research Environment
ID.creator: Avaaz Innovations Inc.
Avaaz Innovations Inc.
info1@avaaz.com
ID.description:
CSRE (pronounced "Caesar") is a comprehensive, DOS-based signal analysis, editing, synthesis and processing system. It contains tools for sampling, editing and managing digital audio signals, and a suite for signal analysis and display. Time-frequency response analyses extract the time-frequency-amplitude coordinates of any signal and display the results as interactive, color or gray-scale spectrograms. Pitch extraction techniques allow accurate estimation of voice fundamental frequency. CSRE allows you to digitize signals with CD quality, and it provides integrated playback, signal editing, analysis, synthesis, display and measurement functions. The parametric speech synthesizer (Klatt 80), includes tools for the efficient generation of experimental signals, including copy synthesis, default parameters and a system for generating synthetic speech continua.
CSRE runs on multi-media PCs under Windows 98/95/3.1x. A restricted range of audio hardware is supported (16-bit i/o, ISA cards from Creative Labs or the state-of-the-art Tucker Davis system).
speech analysis, editing, synthesis and processing systemsystem

ID.title: TFR: The Time-Frequency Representation System
ID.creator: Avaaz Innovations Inc.
Avaaz Innovations Inc.
info1@avaaz.com
ID.description:
TFR is a comprehensive Windows-based signal analysis, editing and processing system using multimedia Windows computers. It contains efficient tools for sampling, editing and managing digital audio signals, and a suite of advanced techniques for signal analysis and display. Advanced time-frequency response techniques extract the time-frequency-amplitude coordinates of any signal and display the results as interactive, color or gray-scale spectrograms. Advanced pitch extraction techniques allow accurate estimation of fundamental frequency. TFR supports these analytical capabilities by allowing you to digitize signals with CD quality, and it provides integrated playback, signal editing, analysis, display and measurement functions, plus digital filtering, digital signal synthesis and many other functions.
Required audio hardware: any Windows-compatible audio hardware (any Windows-compliant audio card or the state-of-the-art Tucker Davis system).
a comprehensive speech/signal analysis, editing and processing system

ID.title: IVANS: The Interactive Voice ANalysis System
ID.creator: Avaaz Innovations Inc.
Avaaz Innovations Inc.
info1@avaaz.com
ID.description:
IVANS is designed specifically for sophisticated, objective, noninvasive, acoustic analysis of vocal function. It offers unique measures that have proven power for assessing voice status, including state-of-the-art, robust measures of voice fundamental frequency (F0), F0 perturbation (jitter and shimmer), glottal noise, and LPC-based and other related, derived measures. These measures have been carefully tested to ensure that they are highly relevant to clinical needs and are highly robust to the effects of voices disorders. These measures are complemented by efficient voice-quality rating protocols and powerful data management and report generation functions.
IVANS runs on any multi-media PC using your choice of Windows-compatible audio hardware (any Windows-compliant audio card or the state-of-the-art Tucker Davis system).
Voice analysis, voice quality rating, voice/client data management

ID.title: ProTrain
ID.creator: Avaaz Innovations Inc.
Avaaz Innovations Inc.
info1@avaaz.com
ID.description: The ProTrain system is used to improve speech production skills by allowing talkers to see and hear key differences between their speech and target (correct) speech samples. Designed for the treatment of phonology and articulation disorders, voice disorders, and foreign accent reduction, ProTrain displays specified parameters of speech to assist clients in reducing speech errors.
speech analysis and speech production training system

ID.title: The OroNasal System
ID.creator: Avaaz Innovations Inc.
Avaaz Innovations Inc.
info1@avaaz.com
ID.description:
The patented OroNasal system consists of a voice-transparent pneumotach mask, with associated electronics and software. The system measures and displays the ratio of nasal-to-oral voiced airflow during speech at the voice fundamental frequency -- the component of speech that best represents the oral/nasal division of the pulsation of airflow generated by the larynx. The mask technology minimizes sound "cross-leakage" between the nose and mouth, and interference from outside sources.
This exclusive measurement technique makes measurements much less dependent on the vowel or voiced consonant being produced than conventional, microphone-based methods. Unlike other nasality measuring devices, which use a partition plate between microphones at the nose and mouth, the operation of the OroNasal System is scientifically specifiable, so it does not require arbitrary, empirically-adjusted mechanical and electronic bias parameters.
Nasalance measurement, analysis of oral and nasal airflow/energy in speech

ID.title: Sprachlabor/Speechlab
ID.creator: Ingolf Franke
Media Enterprise
info@media-enterprise.de
ID.description:
Sprachlabor/Speechlab combine a multimedial introduction to speech science with a complete data base of the German/English phonemes. Each phoneme is represented by videos, X-ray, sagittal view, palatogram, spectrogram, lpc, oscillogram, IPA-sign, speech sample and a short description. Also included is a speech analysis program to display speech signals, spectrogram and FFTs.
Finally there is a large bibliography with more than 4000 entries of linguistic / phonetic papers.
a multimedial introductioin to speech science combined with speech analysis

ID.title: Signalyze(tm)
ID.creator: Eric Keller
Universite de Lausanne
eric.keller@imm.unil.ch
ID.description:
Signalyze 3.0 is an interactive program for the analysis of speech and other acoustic material. It contains a large set of signal editing, signal analysis and signal manipulation tools. Signalyze 3.0 runs on almost all versions of the Macintosh. With a Macintosh AV or a Power Macintosh, you have all you need to record, analyze and reproduce professional 16-bit sound.

Signalyze(tm) 3.0 is distributed by Agora Language Marketplace
Interactive program for speech/signal analysis (runs only on Macintosh)

ID.title: CSL -- Computerized Speech Lab
ID.creator: Kay Elemetrics
Kay Elemetrics
info@kayelemetrics.com
ID.description: CSL is available in two models, Models 4300B and Model 4100. These two hardware platforms share many similarities; however, Model 4100 does not have all of the features of Model 4300B, and it is less expensive. Both CSL models are input/output audio devices for a PC and support the specifications and features needed for reliable acoustic measurements. A rich array of CSL software is available for this device. Not just a "sound card", CSL provides a robust, professional-level, no-compromise hardware platform, integrated with the software, to include reliable speech/signal acquisition, analysis, and playback.
speech acquisition, analysis and playback

ID.title: Multi-Speech
ID.creator: Kay Elemetrics
Kay Elemetrics
info@kayelemetrics.com
ID.description:
Multi-Speech, Model 3700, is a low-cost, Windows-based, speech analysis program, which uses standard multimedia hardware (e.g., Sound Blaster boards) to capture, analyze, and play speech samples.
Multi-Speech can be used for teaching, research, voice measurements, clinical feedback, second language articulation, and forensic work.
a comprehensive speech recording, analysis, feedback, and measurement software program

ID.title: WinSAL-V
ID.creator: Ingolf Franke
Media Enterprise
info@media-enterprise.de
ID.description:
WinSAL-V is a "Speech Audio Lab with Video function" for Windows, a tool for digital speech analysis on the PC. It provides an easy-to-use package of numerous speech analysis functions for sound-wav-files and video-avi-files.
On the audio side, you can record segment or play WAV-files on any soundcard that provides a Windows driver. The playing is restricted to the standard PCM format. Parts of a signal can be zoomed and played or saved seperately. If you save a segment, it will always be a mono file. Recording allows 16 or 8 bit at various frequencies.
a tool for digital speech analysis on the PC

ID.title: CSLU Toolkit
ID.creator: Center for Spoken Language Understanding
Center for Spoken Language Understanding at Oregon Graduate Institute of Science and Technology
edayan@cse.ogi.edu
ID.description: The CSLU Toolkit was created to provide the basic framework and tools for people to build, investigate and use interactive language systems. These systems incorporate leading-edge speech recognition, natural language understanding, speech synthesis and facial animation technologies. The toolkit provides a comprehensive, powerful and flexible environment for building interactive language systems that use these technologies, and for conducting research to improve them.
a comprehensive suite of tools to enable exploration, learning, and research into speech and human-computer interaction

ID.title: Pinocchio
ID.creator: Fabio Ciravegna and Alberto Lavelli
ITC-Irst - Centro per la Ricerca Scientifica e Tecnologica, via Sommarive 18, Povo, Trento, Italy
cirave@irst.itc.it
ID.description: Pinocchio is a toolkit for developing and running Information Extraction applications. New applications and languages can be covered by just writing declarative resources. Information is represented uniformly through the architecture: all the modules use the same input structure and the same type of declarative resources. Modules are implemented via the same basic processors and share a common environment for resource development and debugging. The development environment for resources includes a rich graphical interface with specialised editors, graphers, debuggers and tracers. For running applications within the user environment, a delivery configuration is available with reduced hardware and software requirements. The result is an environment easy to use with limited training and skills. Pinocchio is largely language independent: it has been used in applications for Italian, but demonstrators exist for English and (partially) Russian.
A toolkit for developing and running Information Extraction applications

ID.title: PC-KIMMO
ID.creator: PC-KIMMO project
Academic Computing Department of Summer Institute of Linguistics
WWW@sil.org
ID.description: PC-KIMMO is a new implementation for microcomputers of a program dubbed KIMMO after its inventor Kimmo Koskenniemi (see Koskenniemi 1983). It is of interest to computational linguists, descriptive linguists, and those developing natural language processing systems. The program is designed to generate (produce) and/or recognize (parse) words using a two-level model of word structure in which a word is represented as a correspondence between its lexical level form and its surface level form.
Two-level morphological analyzer

ID.title: WordNet - a Lexical Database for English
ID.creator: George Miller, Christian Fellbaum and many others
Cognitive Science Laboratory at Princeton University
wordnet@princeton.edu.
ID.description: WordNet is an on-line lexical reference system whose design is inspired by current psycholinguistic theories of human lexical memory. English nouns, verbs, and adjectives are organized into synonym sets, each representing one underlying lexical concept. Different relations link the synonym sets.
on-line lexical reference system

ID.title: Transformation-Based Part of Speech Tagger
ID.creator: Eric Brill
Johns Hopkins University, Department of Computer Science
brill@microsoft.com
ID.description: The trainable transformation-based part of speech tagger has achieved higher rates of tagging accuracy than traditional stochastic taggers. Linguistic information is captured in a small number of simple rules (fewer than 200), compared with tens of thousands of opaque probabilities in stochastic taggers. Included with the tagger are modules for tagging unknown words and for k-best tagging.
rule-based part-of-speech tagging

ID.title: TFS -- Typed Feature Structures System
ID.creator: Martin C. Emele
IMS, University of Stuttgart
emele@ims.uni-stuttgart.de
ID.description: The Typed Feature Structure (TFS) representation formalism is an attempt to provide a synthesis of several of the key concepts of unification-based grammar formalisms (feature structures), knowledge representation languages (inheritance) and logic programming (logical variables and declarativity). The inheritance-based constraint architecture embodied in the TFS system integrates two computational paradigms: the object-oriented approach offers complex, recursive, possibly nested, record objects represented as typed feature structures with attribute-value restrictions and (in)equality constraints, and multiple inheritance; the relational programming approach offers declarativity, logical variables, non-determinism with backtracking, and existential query evaluation. The interpreter of the formalism is described as a term rewriting system based on type unfolding where unification of typed feature structures is used to detect inconsistencies between a query and the constraints imposed by the feature type system.
Constraint-based Representation Formalism

ID.title: GULP -- Graph Unification Logic Programming
ID.creator: Michael A. Covington
Artificial Intelligence Center at The University of Georgia
mc@uga.edu
ID.description: A preprocessor for handling feature structures, such as case:nom..number:plural, in Prolog programs. It solves a pesky problem with Prolog, i.e., the lack of a good way to represent feature structures in which features are identified by name rather than position
an extension of Prolog for unification-based grammar

ID.title: JUMAN
ID.creator: Prof.Nagao
Nagao Lab at the University of Kyoto
webmaster@pine.kuee.kyoto-u.ac.jp
ID.description: The JUMAN system is a flexible Japanese morphological analyzer that is easily customized by the users. Definition of Japanese morphological grammar system, such as the set of part of speech, inflection rules, and connection rules of morphemes are easily redefined by users.
a morphological analyzer for Japanese

ID.title: FLEMM
ID.creator: Fiammetta Namer
Equipe LANDIEquipe LANDISCO, UFR Sciences du Langage, Université Nancy 2
namer@clsh.univ-nancy2.fr
ID.description:
FLEMM is a Perl program performing the flexional morphological analysis of french texts, which have been previously tagged (using the Brill Tagger or TreeTagger), and extracts the lemma of the words.
FLEMM is a small rule-based program also using a small lexicon (3000 items) for handling the exceptions.
lemmatizer and morphological analysis for French

ID.title: Fastr
ID.creator: Christian Jacquemin
Groupe Langage et Cognition, CNRS-LIMSI
jacquemin@limsi.fr
ID.description:
Fastr is a parser for term and variant recognition. Fastr take as input a corpus and a list of terms and ouputs the indexed corpus in which terms and variants are recognized.
Fastr can be used in two modes:
-- controlled indexing: input consists of a corpus and a list of terms,
-- free indexing: input only consists of a corpus, the list of terms is automatically acquired from the corpus.
The formalism of Fastr is close to PATR-II.
A tool for automatic indexing and for terminology extraction

ID.title: PAPPI
ID.creator: Sandiway Fong, with contributions from Erwin Kloeck and summer students
NEC Research Institute, Inc.
sandiway@research.nj.nec.com
ID.description: The PAPPI system is a multilingual parser for modern linguistic theory. It is based on the Principles-and-Parameters framework (Chomsky) amd aims at implementing a universal grammar: one grammar for multiple languages.
A Parsing System for the Principles-and-Parameters Framework

ID.title: PC-Translator
ID.creator: George Mallard, Ralph Dessau
Linguistic Products Inc.
76474.1515@compuserve.com
ID.description: Success in the international software marketplace demands documentation in multiple languages. PC-Translator is the tool to produce it. PC-Translator supports English to Danish, Dutch, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, and Swedish.
Machine translation for the PC

ID.title: Xerox Part-of-Speech Tagger (XPOST)
ID.creator: Jan Pedersen, Douglass Cutting
Xerox Parc
webmaster@parc.xerox.com
ID.description:
XPOST is a hidden Markov model based part-of-speech tagger. Given a sentence, each token is assigned a part-of-speech ambiguity class from a lexicon (e.g. "package" is in the ambiguity class {noun,verb}). Words not in the lexicon are subjected to suffix analysis. A probabilistic model that assesses the likelihood of particular part-of-speech assignments based on word order is then applied to disambiguate the available choices. The final output is a sentence with each word tagged with the most likely part-of-speech tag.
XPOST can process all the languages for which word order predicts part-of-speech tag.
HMM part-of-speech tagger

ID.title: QDATR
ID.creator: James Kilbury, Petra Barg, Ingrid Renz, Christof Rumpf, Sebastian Varges
Heinrich-Heine-Universität Düsseldorf / Seminar für Allgemeine Sprachwissenschaft
rumpf@uni-duesseldorf.de
ID.description:
QDATR is an implementation of the DATR formalism developed at the University of Sussex by Roger Evans and Gerald Gazdar: "DATR is a formal language for representing a restricted class of inheritance networks, permitting both multiple and default inheritance. The principle intended area of application is the representation of lexical entries for natural language processing..."
QDATR supports syntactic analysis, text generation, machine translation and can be used for testing linguistic theories making use of non-monotonic inheritances.
An implementation of the DATR formalism

ID.title: DATR
ID.creator: Roger Evans, Gerald Gazdar and Bill Keller
School of Cognitive and Computing Sciences at the University of Sussex
Roger.Evans@itri.bton.ac.uk
ID.description:
Much recent research on the design of natural language lexicons has made use of nonmonotonic inheritance networks as originally developed for general knowledge representation purposes in Artificial Intelligence. DATR is a simple, spartan language for defining nonmonotonic inheritance networks with path/value equations, one that has been designed specifically for lexical knowledge representation.
A set of standard DATR functions that can be invoked, rather than defined, by a DATR description is available to the user.
A formalism for lexical knowledge representation

ID.title: Twente Word Alignment
ID.creator: Djoerd Hiemstra
University of Twente
hiemstra@cs.utwente.nl
ID.description: Within the Twenty-One project a new statistics based method for the automatic extraction of bilingual lexicons was developed. The method inputs a bilingual corpus (that is: a text and its translation in another language) and outputs a bilingual lexicon. The method has advantages over algorithms that have been published before, because it is based on a symmetric translation model. The resulting bilingual lexicon can be used to translate in both directions between a language pair.
Word Alignment tool

ID.title: ALE -- Attribute-Logic Engine
ID.creator: Bob Carpenter and Gerald Penn
Carnegie Mellon University
gpenn+@cmu.edu
ID.description: ALE 3.2, a freeware system written in Prolog integrates phrase structure parsing, semantic-head-driven generation and constraint logic programming with typed feature structures as terms. This generalizes both the feature structures of PATR-II and the terms of Prolog II to allow type inheritance and appropriateness specifications for features and values. Arbitrary constraints may be attached to types, and types may be declared as having extensional structural identity conditions. Grammars may also interleave unification steps with logic program goal calls (as can be done in DCGs), thus allowing parsing to be interleaved with other system components. ALE was developed with an eye toward Head-Driven Phrase Structure Grammar (HPSG), but it can also execute PATR-II grammars, definite clause grammars (DCGs), Prolog, Prolog-II, and LOGIN programs, etc. With suitable coding, it can also execute several aspects of Lexical-Functional Grammar (LFG).
general attribute-value grammar formalism

ID.title: Pulavan
ID.creator: Vasu Ranganathan,
Penn Language Center, University of Pennsylvania
vasur@sas.upenn.edu
ID.description: This work is mainly concerned about the development of a morphological analyzer, parser and a lexial inheritance system for the Tamil language, a highly inflectional and agglutinative language of the Dravidian family. Some of the intended applications are language learning, word processor utilities, Tamil interface system and machine translation.
morphological analyzer, parser and a lexial inheritance system for the Tamil language

ID.title: SNePS -- Semantic Network Processing System
ID.creator: Stuart C. Shapiro and The SNePS Implementation Group
Department of Computer Science and Engineering, StateUniversity of New York at Buffalo
shapiro@cse.buffalo.edu
ID.description: NePS is a logic- and network- based knowledge representation, reasoning, and acting system, based on a monotonic, paraconsistent, first-order term logic, with compositional intensional semantics. It has an ATMS-style facility for belief contraction, an acting component, including a well-defined syntax and semantics for primitive and composite acts, as well as for rules that allow for acting in support of reasoning and reasoning in support of acting, and a natural language processing system, consisting of an English morphological analyzer and synthesizer, and a Generalized Augmented Transition Network (GATN) Grammar interpreter/compiler.
knowledge-representation/reasoning system

ID.title: LexiGraf
ID.creator: Yiannis C Hatzopoulos
SES Ltd Greece.
yhat@egnatia.ee.auth.gr
ID.description: The LexiGraf 2.1 software base has been developed under the MS- WINDOWS operating system to assist the creation of multilingual and bilingual terminology dictionaries in print. Any language combination supported by MS-Windows can be accomodated to a maximum of 8 (single-byte language sets for the 16bit LexiGraf). The system offers direct transition from terminology collection to the printing press; provides terminology management services; LAN use and excellent quality output to typesetters for subsequent printing-press reproduction.
a multilingual lexicography software environment

ID.title: Praat
ID.creator: Paul Boersma and David Weenink
Institute of Phonetic Sciences of the University ofAmsterdam
paul.boersma@hum.uva.nl
ID.description:
The computer program Praat is a research, publication, and productivity tool for phoneticians.

This comprehensive speech analysis, synthesis, and manipulation package includes general numerical and statistical stuff, is built on a general-purpose GUI shell for handling objects, and produces publication-quality graphics.

The software is freely downloadable, but should not be redistributed without advicing the authors.
a research, publication, and productivity tool for phoneticians

ID.title: MBROLA
ID.creator: TCTS Lab of the Faculté Polytechnique de Mons
TCTS Lab of the Faculté Polytechnique de Mon
mbrola@tcts.fpms.ac.be
ID.description: MBROLA ia a speech synthesizer based on the concatenation of diphones. It takes a list of phonemes as input, together with prosodic information (duration of phonemes and a piecewise linear description of pitch), and produces speech samples on 16 bits (linear), at the sampling frequency of the diphone database used (it is therefore NOT a Text-To-Speech (TTS)synthesizer, since it does not accept raw text as input)
a speech synthesizer based on the concatenation of diphones

ID.title: EULER
ID.creator: TCTS Lab at the Faculté Polytechnique de Mons
TCTS Lab at the Faculté Polytechnique de Mons
euler@tcts.fpms.ac.be
ID.description:
It is a freely available (GNU C++), easy-to-use, and easy-to-extend, generic TTS for Windows95/98/NT. French is currently supported; other langages will follow. A Mac Port is in the works. A Unix (Linux) port will follow.
EULER comes as an auto-installable package composed of a series of modules compiled as dynamically linked libraries (DLL). Each module can be adapted to a very easily specific language by using ad-hoc language-dependent databases, the format of which has been chosen maximally compatible with existing standards. Modules are connected to a central multi-level container (MLC) and , which called sequentially as specified in a simple run-time script. Sample EULER-based TTS applications are also provided.

EULER modules are also provided as GNU C++ source code when possible. If not, they are provided as DLLs.
EULER databases are made available in a compact format, in order to protect the rights of database providers. All EULER modules, however, can read both compacted and non-compacted versions of databases, so that EULER users can easily develop (or port) their own databases and test them inside EULER, before making them publicly available in a compact format.

EULER is related to the MBROLA synthesizer.
a freely available, easy-to-use, and easy-to-extend, generic multilingual TTS

ID.title: Txt2pho
ID.creator: Institute for Communications Research and Phonetics, University of Bonn
Institute for Communications Research and Phonetics, University of Bonn
tpo@ikp.uni-bonn.de
ID.description: A German TTS front end for the MBROLA synthesizer. Txt2pho is the free version of the speech synthesis system Hadifix, a system which synthesizes a speech signal from orthographic input after converting this into phonemes. Stress and phrasing are generated automatically. For the synthesis, a library of small units of natural speech is used; these units are concatenated. For example, the word "Strolch" is formed by concatenating "Stro" and "olch".
German TTS front end for the MBROLA synthesizer

ID.title: BOMP
ID.creator: Thomas Portele, Dieter Stock
Institut für Kommunikationsforschung und Phonetik, University of Bonn
sbr@ikp.uni-bonn.de
ID.description:
BOMP is a machine-readable pronunciation dictionary for German with more than 50.000 entries - all of them checked.

The dictionary has been adapted for the use in the speech synthesis system Hadifix (Hadifix) or its freely available derivate (Txt2pho also described here in the NLSR).
machine-readable pronunciation dictionary for German

ID.title: AGFL Grammar Work Lab
ID.creator: Department of Software Engineering, University of Nijmegen
Department of Software Engineering, University of Nijmegen.
www-agfl@cs.kun.nl
ID.description:
AGFL (Affix Grammars over Finite Lattices) is a formalism in which context free grammars can be described. AGFLs are two level grammars: a first, context free level is augmented with features for expressing agreement between parts of speech.

AGFL is distributed under the GNU General Public License (GNU GPL).
Formalism and tools for context free grammars

ID.title: Zdatr
ID.creator: Dafydd Gibbon (Bielefeld) and Grigoriy Strokin (Moscow)
University of Bielefeld and Lomonossov University
gibbon@spectrum.uni-bielefeld.de
ID.description:
The Zdatr 2.0 engine is a DATR implementation in ANSI C for UNIX and Windows95/NT. It is distributed under the GNU General Public License in source code with installation scripts, and the recommended compiler distribution is gcc. DATR is a knowledge representation language originally developed by Gazdar and Evans at the Universitiy of Sussex (see also the DATR entry here in the Registry, or directly the DATR page).

Zdatr was originally designed in by Dafydd Gibbon and Chrisoph Schillo in 1995 to provide convenient high-speed piped batch or interactive standard DATR query processing with very large DATR theories, convenient I/O, and system IPC interfaces to CGI and other processes. It was revised and extended by Grigoriy Strokin and Dafydd Gibbon in 1997-1999.

The requirements and design specifications and the implementation architecture are based on almost a decade experience in implementing DATR for teaching and project applications in Bielefeld in a number of different styles: in Scheme (DDATR in the now defunct PC-Scheme; recently PalmDATR for PalmOS) for small-scale development purposes, Prolog (NODE), for generating the large VERBMOBIL project lexicon, and with UNIX tools (MUD), for driving a CGI interface on the web. Zdatr has been used in various versions as the underlying engine for web-based DATR applications on the Bielefeld web site since 1996.
The Zdatr 2.0 system is split into two independent modules, a tokenizer (zdatrtok) for preprocessing of a theory, and the inference engine (zdatrinf), which permits queries to be processed via manual input, or query declaration files or query list files details). An interface is also provided for a number of standard invocations of Zdatr 2.0.
Zdatr is a standardised DATR implementation in ANSI C

ID.title: Mind.Forth
ID.creator: Arthur T. Murray
independent scholar
mentifex@scn.org
ID.description: A general-purpose linguistic AI for robots.
rudimentary AI mind

ID.title: LearningPinocchio
ID.creator: Fabio Ciravegna
ITC-IRST - Centro per la Ricerca Scientifica e Tecnologica, via Sommarive 18, Povo (Tn), I-38050, Italy
cirave@irst.itc.it
ID.description: LearningPinocchio is a system for adaptive information extraction from text that learns template filling rules from tagged corpora. The system is adaptable to new scenarios and domains by the final user via corpus tagging. LP design maximizes the usability by the final user and tops the current state of the art in terms of effectiveness in extracting information. The system has been tested on Italian and English, but it is extendible to cover other languages in a simple way: it just requires the connection of a Part of speech tagger and/or a morphological analyzer for the target language. The adaptability and effectiveness of LP was demonstrated in a number of scientific experiments and industrial applications. From a scientific point of view it has been tested on three scenarios in informal domains in two languages (Italian and English). Experiments report excellent results with respect to the current state of the art, as in all of them LP reached results that to our knowledge (July 2000) are the best ever obtained on such corpora by a system for adaptive IE. Real-world applications have been developed or are under development for a number of companies. They concern Named Entity Recognition from financial news for Italian, data extraction from personal resumees in English, information extraction from classified articles in Italian. LearningPinocchio is also under consideration for two industrial projects in the area of pharmaceutical research.
a system for adaptive information extraction from text that learns template filling rules from tagged corpora.

ID.title: Minipar
ID.creator: Dekang Lin
University of Alberta
lindek@cs.ualberta.ca
ID.description: A principle-based broad-coverage parser for English.
A principle-based broad-coverage parser for English

IMS, University of Stuttgart

ID.description: The TreeTagger is a tool for the annotation of corpora with part-of-speech information. Parameter files for English, German, Italian and French are available. The tagger can be trained for further languages.

ID.title: LoPar

ID.description: LoPar is a context-free chart parser for symbolic, probabilistic and head-lexicalised probabilistic parsing and training. LoPar can be used to generate Viterbi parses, parse forests with or without probability information, most probable tag (or chunk) sequences and much more.
a head-lexicalised probabilistic parser

ID.title: YAP
ID.creator: Helmut Schmid
IMS, University of Stuttgart
Helmut.Schmid@ims.uni-stuttgart.de
ID.description: YAP is an efficient parser for a lean unification-based grammar formalism (the YAP formalism). It comes with a simple Emacs-based grammar development environment. YAP is able to compile a subset of the feature constraints into a context-free grammar and can therefore also be used as a comfortable development tool for context-free grammars.
an efficient unification-based parser

ID.title: VPF
ID.creator: Helmut Schmid
IMS, University of Stuttgart
Helmut.Schmid@ims.uni-stuttgart.de
ID.description: VPF is a graphical parse forest browser for context-free and feature-based parsers.
a graphical parse forest browser

Rijksuniversiteit Groningen and Technical University of Gdansk
jandac@pg.gda.pl
ID.description: A set of programs creating and using finite-state automata for spell-checking, morphological analysis, perfect hashing, diacritic restoration, computer-assisted addition of new words into a morphological lexicon.
finite-state utilities for nlp

Columbia University
min@cs.columbia.edu
ID.description: This is a software package in perl written by Min-Yen Kan, under the guidance of Profs. Kathy McKeown and Judith L. Klavans to perform segmentation of texts into topical chunks.
A linear multiparagraph topic segmentation program

ID.title: Leximancer
ID.creator: Andrew E. Smith
Leximancer
enquiries@leximancer.com
ID.description:
A fast Automatic Document Mapping system for large document sets. Leximancer allows the user to select concepts of interest, or it can choose them automatically to reflect the themes of the documents. It then learns the optimal set of words to describe each concept and tags the text with these concepts down to a sentence resolution. The tagged text is then indexed, and the concepts are clustered. The resulting concept map gives an overview of the data set, shows quantitative relationships, and allows drill-down to text.

The system can be quickly extended to support languages other than English.
Fast Automatic Document Mapping System

ID.title: Onix
ID.creator: Art Pollard
Lextek International
pollarda@lextek.com
ID.description: Onix is a high performance information retrieval toolkit that can be integrated into a wide variety of applications. Onix provides an easy to use API and is capable of working with a wide variety of languages and character sets. Used currently used to power both small applications (such as ebook readers) and large applications such as web search engines and document management systems.
High performance information retrieval engine

ID.title: Brevity
ID.creator: Art Pollard
Lextek International
pollarda@lextek.com
ID.description: Brevity is a toolkit for adding document summarization to your applications. By providing an easy to use API, Brevity will get you up and going quickly and easily. Results from Brevity may also be used to highlight important sections and keywords within a document.
Document summarization toolkit

ID.title: ROSANA
ID.creator: Roland Stuckardt
Knowbotic Systems GmbH & Co. KG, Frankfurt am Main, Germany
roland@stuckardt.de
ID.description: ROSANA (RObust Syntax-based ANAphor resolution) is a coreference resolution system identifying co-referring antecedents for various types of anaphoric expressions (third person pronouns, possessives, reflexives, common nouns, names). It achieves the goal of robustness by relying on robust preprocessing only, viz. morphological analysis and robust parsing (yielding fragmentary parses). The core of ROSANA consists of a robust generalization of the binding-theoretic disjoint reference conditions to fragmentary syntactic descriptions. In its current version, ROSANA works on English texts. Being based on the linguistic universals of GB theory, however, its core engine is considered to be language independent. ROSANA has been developed entirely in Allegro Common Lisp.
robust coreference resolution

University of Minnesota Duluth
tpederse@d.umn.edu
ID.description: This package supports the analysis of bigrams that appear in text using Fishers exact test, the log likelihood ratio, Pearsons chi-squared text, and the Dice Coefficient. BSP is designed so that you can easily add your own statistics. It is written in Perl and is freely available.
Bigram analysis software

Lehrstuhl für Informatik VI, RWTH Aachen - University of Technology
translation@i6.informatik.rwth-aachen.de
ID.description: For a set of test sentences and translation hypotheses, EvalTrans facilitates human evaluation of each translation by storing each evaluation in a database and presenting similar translations in it. EvalTrans will calculate miscellaneous quality metrics, and can also extrapolate evaluations using database entries.
Evaluation tool with GUI using reference database

ID.title: GlossaNet
ID.creator: Cédrick Fairon
LADL, Université Marne-la-Vallée (Paris)
cf40@nyu.edu
ID.description:
Free On-line concordancer based on electronic dictionaries and local grammars. The system allows the user to choose a Newspaper (in a preselected pool of 25 newspapers in 5 languages) and to register a request. Every day, the system download the edition of the day of the selected newspaper and apply the user's request. Results, if any, are sent by e-mail under the form of an HTML concordance. GlossaNet is mainly used for information retrieval in newspapers, research in linguistics and teaching computational linguistics.

GlossaNet is for the time being accessible only on-line. A standalone application is under development, and will be soon available for distribution.
Free On-line concordancer based on electronic dictionaries and local grammars.

ID.title: PWA
ID.creator: Jörg Tiedemann, Mikael Andersson, Magnus Merkel, Lars Ahrenberg, Anna Sågvall Hein
Department of Linguistics, Uppsala University; Department of Computer and Information Science, Linköping University, Sweden
pwa@stp.ling.uu.se
ID.description: The PLUG Word Aligner (PWA) is a collection of tools for the automatic alignment of word correspondences in bilingual parallel texts. The system integrates a set of modules for knowledge-lite approaches to word alignment, with various possibilities to change configuration and to adapt the system to other language pairs and text types. The system requires sentence aligned bitexts as its input and produces a list of word and phrase correspondences in the text (link instances) and an additional bilingual lexicon from these instances (type links). PWA comprises 2 word alignment systems, the Linköping Word Aligner (LWA) and the Uppsala Word Aligner (UWA). Both system were developed within the the co-operative project on parallel text, PLUG, that was carried out between November, 1997 and March, 2000. The system was developed at the Department of Computer and Information Science at Linköping University, Linköping/Sweden and the Department of Linguistics at Uppsala University, Uppsala/Sweden. PWA integrates both systems in the modular corpus toolbox Uplug and includes additional tools for the automatic generation of monolingual word collocations (phrases) and for the automated evaluation of alignment results (the PLUG Scorer - PLS).
Word Aligner

ID.title: Kura
ID.creator: Boudewijn Rempt
Unaffiliated
boud@rempt.xs4all.nl
ID.description: ura is a complete, professional system for the handling of linguistic data, especially fieldwork data from small-corpus languages. It allows users to enter texts in any language, analyze those texts and bring the analyzed linguistic facts into relation with each other. Kura includes both a desktop application for easy handling of interlinear texts, lexica and other linguistic data, and a special-purpose webserver for the online presentation of the analyzed data.
Kura is a system for the analysis and presentation of linguistic data such as interlinear texts.

a speech visualization and transcription tool

ID.title: Pertinence
ID.creator: A. Lehmam, P. Bouvet
Pertinence
lehmam@freesurf.fr
ID.description:
Pertinence is a tool mapping a text in a shorter one, while preserving the relevant information. The generated text is a set of sentences selected according to their importance in the text. The user can parametrize the length of the summary.
Pertinence summarizes currently only French, English and Spanish texts, but the linguistic method in use in Pertinence allows to extend the functionality to other languages. Pertinence applies to *.txt*, HTML, PDF, RTF and Word documents.
Through its access to specialized linguistic resources, Pertinence is specially performant on summarizing domain-specific texts.
Various levels of blue colour in the summarized text support the reading and allow the detection by the reader of the parts of the text that are considered important.

ID.description: Anvil is a generic tool for the annotation of digitized video with linguistic, nonverbal and other descriptive data. Annotation takes place on freely definable, multiple layers (tracks) by inserting objects with attribute-value pairs. The generic approach allows the application of various annotation schemes. It provides methods for cross-level linkage. It is platform-independent, XML-based and fitted with an intuitive GUI.
Generic video annotation tool with multiple layers and cross-level links

ID.creator: Andrew Bredenkamp
DFKI
