ID.title: VisualText (TM)
ID.creator: Text Analysis International, Inc.
Text Analysis International, Inc.
info@textanalysis.com
ID.description: VisualText is an Integrated Development Environment for building deep text analysis applications. Think of it like Visual C++(R) for Natural Language Processing applications. It is loaded with features to make the development of NLP applications much more productive, including NLP++ (TM) -- a new C++ -like programming language especially designed for building deep text analyzers. VisualText supports rapid development and enhancement of a wide range of text analyzer applications: e.g., deep information extraction, categorization, and summarization, to name a few. It dramatically reduces needed programming resources, and analyzers developed with it are highly extensible - even non-linguists can enhance existing analyzers. Complex text analyzers can be fully developed, even deployed, in interpreted mode, or compiled for faster processing. VisualText lowers NLP development costs, gets applications to market faster, helps develop deeper text analysis applications, and enhances the extension, customization and maintenance of text analyzers. And through its runtime Application Programming Interface, text analyzers can readily integrate with broader software applications.
Integrated Development Environment for building deep text analysis applications

TALaNa - INRIA

ID.description: XLFG is a new parser for LFG. It is written in C, using an LR algorithm (Knuth 1965). We have tried to put an emphasis on the user-friendliness, thanks to a Graphical User Interface (GUI) developed in Tcl/Tk and to provide a fast and ergonomical way to encode and test LFG grammars. XLFG is highly portable and is publicly available with a GPL licence. Both the program and the source code can be downloaded on the www for most platforms.
Syntactic analysis using the LFG formalism

TRIZ-CHANCE
soft@triz-chance.spb.ru
ID.description: "Journalism and public relations techniques" (version 2.02). Being based on the analysis of 12.500 works of world-known fiction writers, journalists and copy writers it can be used for composing texts of books, feature stories and articles in different fields; scripts for audio- and videoclips; press-releases; texts for oral presentations; also it can be used in the fields of public relations and students training. Program users are: - advertising agencies staff; marketing, advertising and PR departments staff; companies staff; - journalists, editors and publishers; - pre-election headquarters staff; - university and business schools instructors, especially in the following subjects: literature, rhetoric, stylistics, journalism, advertising and PR, marketing, sociology, psychology, politology, pedagogics and direction. All programs are developed for the class of systems "decision making support", i.e. programs don't substitute the Author, but intensively help him in the text development. ID.title: Galaxy Communicator Software Infrastructure
ID.creator: MITRE Corporation
MITRE Corporation
darpacomm@linus.mitre.org
ID.description: The Galaxy Communicator software infrastructure (GCSI) is an open source infrastructure for constructing dialogue systems. Its plug-and-play hub-and-spoke approach enables developers to combine architecture-compliant commercial software and cutting edge research components. This work is funded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) of the United States Government. The GCSI distribution includes server bindings in C, Python, Java and Allegro Common Lisp; a central, scriptable hub with logging capabilities; sample servers; and extensive documentation and examples.
Open source hub-and-spoke infrastructure for constructing dialogue systems

ID.title: BETSY - Bayesian Essay Test Scoring sYstem
ID.creator: Lawrence m. Rudner
University of Maryland
rudner@ericae.net
ID.description: BETSY is a windows-based program that classifies text based on trained material. It was designed for automated essay scoring and can be applied to any text classification task. Features include 1) Multinomial or Bernoulli Naive Bayes models 2) Optional Porter stemming 3) Re-entrant training 4) Popular database format 5) Output on screen and into CSV files 6) Training file trimming 7) Infrequent term purge 8) Web interface 9) Diagnostic information 10) Up to 5 score categories 11) Free
Free Windows based text classifier/essay scorer

ID.title: TerminologyExtractor
ID.creator: Etienne Cornu
Chamblon Systems Inc., Cambridge, Ontario, Canada
etienne@chamblon.com
ID.description:
TerminologyExtractor is a tool that extracts word and collocation lists, with frequencies, from Microsoft Word document, HTML, Rich-Text Format and plain text files.
TerminologyExtractor uses a number of features and algorithms to provide the best possible output. For example, when processing English and French texts, it uses the root form of each word, i.e. it transforms plurals and conjugated verbs into singulars and infinitves. It also uses lists of control words (pronouns, articles, prepositions, etc.) to avoid collocations such as "of the" and "I have". Also, all acronyms and proper nouns are kept in their original form; no changes are made to uppercase and lowercase letters.
One of the main features of TerminologyExtractor is that it differentiates between words and non-words. TerminologyExtractor marks a string as "word" if it is found in its dictionary. Otherwise, the string is marked as "non-word". After TerminologyExtractor has processed a set of documents, the non-word list contains abreviations, proper nouns, misspelled words and words that are very specific to the domain of the text. These can therefore be immediately spotted without having to manually go through a long list of words.
The collocation lists produced by TerminologyExtractor contain all sequences of words and non-words that appear more than once in the text. A special algorithm allows it to see collocations that appear within longer collocations. For example, in a text about law you may find the terms "justice system" and "criminal justice system". These terms will both appear in the collocation list with their respective frequency.
A tool for extracting terminology from small and large documents

ID.title: EasyAsk

Ecquis (EasyAsk in Europe)
simon@ecquis.com

Software which converts Natural language into SQL for common databse platforms as well as serach indexes.Greater than 90% understanding.

University of Sussex, Microsoft Research, YY Technologies

Efficiency in Large-Scale Parsing Systems - Parser Comparison

English lemmatizer and morphological generator

ID.description: Morphix is a very fast and robust morphological component for German. Besides inflectional analysis, it analyses compounds and is also able to generate wordforms from a given stem entry and some further morpho-syntactic information.

Corpus analysis tollbox

Free Schooling

Utrecht institute of Linguistics OTS, Utrecht University
Johan.Kerstens@let.uu.nl
ID.description: A Web-based lexicon for linguists. To search the lexicon, type a keyword or browse through the alphabetic list.

ID.title: emdros

University of Aalborg
emdros@yahoo.dk
ID.description: Emdros is a text database engine for linguistic analysis and research. It permits storage and retrieval of "text plus information about that text" through a query-language that permits creation, update, deletion, and query of the data domains provided.
text database engine for linguistic analysis and research

ID.title: fnTBL
ID.creator: Radu Florian and Grace Ngai
Johns Hopkins University
rflorian@cs.jhu.edu
ID.description: fnTBL is a fast implementation of Transformation Based Learning (TBL). It is a general-purpose toolkit for classification tasks. It comes pretrained for a number of NLP tasks (English/Swedish POS tagging, base NP identification, text chunking); new tasks are easy to set up. For more information, please visit the toolkit web page at http://nlp.cs.jhu.edu/~rflorian/fntbl
Fast Transformation-Based Learning System

ID.title: QuickTag
ID.creator: Cogilex R&D inc.
Cogilex R&D inc.
Info@Cogilex.com
ID.description:
QuickParse is used to efficiently parse english text (i.e. identify grammatical role of words and grammatical links between words) and extract semantic content of different types. Cogilex can customize a version of QuickParse for your specific needs or can develop a complete solution for you.
Parsing uses a dependency approach based on lexical representation and grammatical rules.
Result of parsing preserves all amibiguities so they can be resolved semantically. Result of parse is shown as lexical frames attached to specific words in the sentence.
QuickParse can work with discontinuous text, speech transcripts, incomplete sentences, technical texts, etc.
QuickParse can parse over 1000 sentences per second on en entry-level Pentium.
a robust and efficient parser for English

ID.title: Malaga
ID.creator: Björn Beutel
Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg
bjoern@linguistik.uni-erlangen.de
ID.description: Malaga is a development environment for Left-Associative Grammars (LAGs). The Left-Associative Grammar is a formalism that describes the analysis and generation of words and sentences strictly from the left to the right. It has been introduced by Roland Hausser (http://www.linguistik.uni-erlangen.de/~rrh). The Grammars for morphological and/or syntactical analysis are written in a special- The language has a Pascal-ish syntax, but it uses a powerful dynamic typing system with attribute-value structures and lists that can be nested. A collection of operators and standard functions. It contains constructs to branch the program execution into parallel paths when a grammatical ambiguity is encountered. The grammars are compiled into virtual code that is executed by an interpreter. The toolkit comprises parser generators for the development of morphological and syntactic parsers (including sample grammars), source-code lexicon/grammar debuggers (with Emacs modes), and an optional visualization tool to display derivation paths and categorial values using GTK+. The toolkit is written in ANSI/ISO-compliant C and its source code is freely available. It can be used and distributed under the terms of the GNU General Public License. It should work out-of-the-box on most POSIX systems. Porting to other platforms should be easy. A Windows port is on its way.
Development Environment and Language for Left Associative Grammars (Morphology and Syntax)

ID.title: ASDParser and ASDEditor
ID.creator: James A. Mason
York University
jmason@yorku.ca
ID.description: Augmented Syntax Diagrams (ASDs) represent grammars as directed graphs. They are as powerful as, but simpler than, ATN grammars. ASDEditor is a graphical editor for ASDs. ASDParser is a left-corner bottom-up backtracking parser for ASDs, with memory for uniquely parsed constituents when it backtracks. Both are implemented in Java 2.
Parser and editor for Augmented Syntax Diagram grammars, implemented in Java.

ID.title: SweSum

KTH, Euroling AB
hercules@euroling.se
ID.description: SweSum is an automatic text summarizer for Swedish, English, French, Spanish and German text
text summarizer SweSum

ID.title: FGW (Functional Grammar Workbench)
ID.creator: Juan C. Ruiz-Antón
General Linguistics - Universitat Jaume I (SPAIN)
ruiz@trad.uji.es

ID.title: XeLDA
ID.creator: Xerox Multilingual Knowledge Management Solutions
Xerox Multilingual Knowledge Management Solutions
xts-support@mkms.xerox.com
ID.description:
XeLDA framework provides a general-purpose system to retrieve text document, execute language processing operations on the content and return results to the user.
XeLDA offers an expanding range of services which draw on a various language processing components to fulfill their functions.
- Language identification: recognizes the language and character set used by a selected text.
- Tokenization: divides the selected text into words.
- Morphological analysis: provides the normalized form and all potential part of speech categories for each word identified during tokenization.
- Part of speech disambiguation: finds the correct grammatical category of a word according to its context within a text.
- Noun phrase extraction: identifies a sequence of words that behaves together as a noun.
- Contextual dictionary lookup: retrieves a word context and uses this context to find the correct entry in the dictionary.
- Idiomatic expression recognition: recognizes idiomatic expressions in a text.
- Relational morphology: groups words according to their derivational family.
- Shallow parsing: provides syntactic annotations on unrestricted texts, such as technical documentation, news articles, and web pages.

Source Languages: Dutch, English, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Czech, Hungarian, Polish, Russian, Danish, Swedish, Finnish Norwegian, and Chinese. In development: Czech, Arabic, Japanese and Korean
Bilingual Dictionaries: English, French and German to English, French,German, Italian and Spanish

Supported Formats: Plain text, HTML, RTF
XeLDA is a linguistic platform including sets of independent components which makes it easy to integrate XeLDA services with other text applications

ID.title: askOnce

ID.description: askOnce is a web-based meta-search application that allows you to search multiple repositories and data-types with a single query. Simply logon to the askOnce server, enter your search criteria, and select the supported information sources you wish to search. Then askOnce goes to work, automatically logging on to each data source, rapidly sifting through massive amounts of data and returning just the information you need. Language is no longer a barrier to finding the right information. You can formulate a query in your mother tongue and askOnce will translate it into the language of the source. When information is returned the askOnce Multi-language Server provides a translation assistant to help the comprehension of foreign language documents. To give even better results, you can use your own company specific multilingual terminology which ensure maximum possible relevancy of results. Everything is presented in a clear, consistent manner on a single screen; just click the document reference to go directly to the source. askOnce can be used by either casual users or by specialized knowledge workers who require high precision query formulation.
askOnce meets the challenge facing most corporate users - how to quickly and easily find relevant multilingual information.

ID.description: MCGTOOLS is an experimental workbench for the development and testing of categorial grammars built by Xavier Lloré according to the specifications of his PhD thesis "A Parsing Method for Multimodal Categorial Grammars", December1995. MCGTOOLS implements the theorem prover based on the translation of categorial formulae to high order linear clauses with difference structures as defined in [Lloré y Morrill 95, Lloré 95]. MCGTOOLS covers the following categorial constructors: associative concatenation, non associative adjunction, infixation, extraction, tuple formation, intensionality, bracketing, unbracketing, quantification over features and empty elements extraction.

ID.description: DGgraph is a PostScript library which is used to generate an arc graph drawing from a specification of a dependency graph (syntax tree). The PostScript file can then be converted into other graphics formats, such as EPS/EPSF, PS, PDF, PNG, GIF, and JPEG. DGgraph allows crossing arcs (discontinuities); it allows each node to contain an arbitrary number of labels, positioned below each other; it can draw two sets of arcs: one set above the nodes, and another set below the nodes; and it splits graphs over several lines and pages, if the graph doesn't fit on one line or page.

ID.title: Sakrament Text to Speech engine v 2.0
ID.creator: Sakrament company
Sakrament company
ales@sakrament.com
ID.description:
The basic characteristics of Sakrament Text-to-Speech Engine v2.0:
  • Fully compliant with the text-to-speech engines industrial standard Microsoft Speech API (SAPI) 5.1;
  • Able to work in telephone lines using TAPI 3;
  • Can be used with any application supporting SAPI 5.1 protocol;
  • Multilingual support. Any language may be defined as a description file with the set of rules and exceptions. At present we've created a full description of the Russian language. Description files for Belarusian, Ukrainian and English are under development;
  • Multivoice support. To activate a new voice it is necessary to install an additional allophone database. Such a database may be created using the customer's voice sample records. The basic set contains 3 voices: 2 male and 1 female one;
  • Accent and dialects creation feature. Using a linguistic module in one language together with the allophone database in another allows of building accents and dialects;
  • Control flexibility. Provides an ability to set prosodic contours for inflexion, volume level, rate and pitch of synthesized voice;
  • Supports a full set of SAPI Speech Tags and additional tags. With the help of tags it is possible to set a stress position, a phonetic notion for a fragment of text, fragment class (date, time, address etc.), prosodic parameters (volume level, rate, inflexion etc.) and other user's defined parameters;
  • Possibility to work with text and XML files.
  • Automatically detects and processes numbers, time, dates, URLs, e-mails, ZIP codes, phone numbers, contractions, abbreviations etc. Linguistic analysis module functionality can be extended by additional text processing plug-ins;
  • Developed on a modular approach. Each module is independent from the others and may be used in other speech synthesis, linguistic processing and sound processing systems.
SAPI 5.x, multilingual TTS SDK

ID.title: MontyTagger v1.0
ID.creator: Hugo Liu
MIT Media Lab
hugo@media.mit.edu
ID.description: Monty Tagger is a rule-based part-of-speech tagger based on Eric Brill's 1994 transformational-based learning POS tagger, and uses Brill-compatible lexicon and rule files. (The distribution includes Brill's original Penn Treebank trained lexicon and rule files.) It also includes a tokenizer for English and tools for performance evaluation. Because it is implemented in classic, portable Python, it will run on virtually any system (i.e. Mac, Unix, Windows) for which a python implementation exists. The API is also available in Java via montytagger.jar. The tagger (running in classic Brill mode) has been benchmarked at 200 words/sec, running in python 2.2 on a pentium-III, 1Ghz Wintel box. Word-level tagging accuracy on typical US English non-fiction is approximately 95% (comparable to Brill). Version 2.0 will hybridize Brill tagging with linguistically motivated techniques aimed at improving POS tagging accuracy in English, including handling of phrasal verbs, idiomatic phrases, shallow parsing, handling of long-distance dependencies, verb selectional preferences, and commonsense selectional preferences.
http://web.media.mit.edu/~hugo/montytagger

ID.creator: global words AG

ID.description: Das cFlow-System ist eine Software zur automatischen Übersetzung von E-mails (z.Zt. in den Sprachrichtungen Deutsch-Englisch, Englisch-Deutsch, Deutsch-Französisch, Französisch-Deutsch). Das Übersetzungssystem beruht auf der Technologie der LOGOS-Engine, die seit ca. 30 Jahren kontinuierlich weiterentwickelt und erweitert wird ; die Abdeckung weiterer Sprachpaare ist geplant. Ziel des Einsatzes der Software ist die Ökonomisierung der im Rahmen des Email-Austausches anfallenden Kommunikationsprozesse. Die Technologie ist fest integrierbar in Trägerprogramme wie Microsoft Outlook® und Lotus Notes®, d.h. der automatische Übersetzungsprozess kann aus dem vom Anwender präferierten Kommunikationsprogramm heraus unmittelbar angesteuert und ausgewählt werden. Die zu übersetzende Email wird automatisch an den Übersetzungsserver übertragen, dort bearbeitet und innerhalb kürzester Zeit übersetzt zurückgesandt. Die konstante Qualitätsverbesserung der Übersetzungsgüte wird gewährleistet durch die Möglichkeit, fachspezifische und anwenderspezifische Terminologie auf einfache Weise in das System einzupflegen.
